org.fluentjava.collections
Class ExtendedSet<E>

java.lang.Object
  java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      java.util.AbstractSet<E>
          java.util.HashSet<E>
              org.fluentjava.collections.ExtendedSet<E>
Type Parameters:
E - Type of elements
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<E>, java.util.Collection<E>, java.util.Set<E>, Enumerable<E>, FluentSet<E>, ExtendedIterable<E>
public class ExtendedSet<E>
extends java.util.HashSet<E>
implements FluentSet<E>

Standard implementation of FluentSet.

See Also:

array

public <T> T[] array(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
Description copied from interface: FluentSet
Simliar to the method toArray, but recieves no args and is type safe. Also, the returned array is just a copy. Note that the class is necessary, as Gererics by themselves cannot solve this problem alone. For more info: http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-jtp01255.html

Specified by:
array in interface FluentSet<E>
Returns:
A copy of the set as an array.

reduce

public E reduce(E initial,
                java.lang.Object closure)
         throws EnumeratingException
Description copied from interface: Enumerable
Combines the elements of Enumerator by applying the closure to an accumulator value (memo) and each element in turn. At each step, memo is set to the value returned by the closure. The first form lets you supply an initial value for memo

Specified by:
reduce in interface Enumerable<E>
Returns:
Throws:
EnumeratingException

reduce

public E reduce(java.lang.Object closure)
         throws EnumeratingException
Description copied from interface: Enumerable
As reduce(E initial, Object closure), but uses the first element of the collection as a the initial value (and skips that element while iterating).

Specified by:
reduce in interface Enumerable<E>

EnumeratingException
